entry.title: Re: Reflection of Offset Amount in the Closing Invoice
entry.content:
In SAP, the standard closing billing statement  typically shows only the net receivable amount after offsetting, because the purpose is to present what the customer owes after clearing mutual payables. However, if your business requirement is to display both the original receivable and the offset payable amounts, then please note that there is no standard setting to show both the amounts.
You need a custom logic form (smart form/adobe form ) to do so.
Option 1
Use Output Management / Smart Forms / Adobe Forms for the billing statement.
Include:
Original Receivable Amount
Offset Payable Amount
Net Amount to be billed
This also requires adding fields from the clearing document or related AP items to the form logic.
Option 2
Instead of modifying the billing statement, you can generate a custom correspondence that lists both AR and AP items for transparency. This is used in Japan 
In SAP Financial Accounting, a correspondence type refers to a predefined category of communication or document that you send to customers, vendors, or internal stakeholders.
 
Configuration Steps
Define Correspondence Type in FI (transaction OB77).
Assign program and form (Smart Form or Adobe Form).
Use BAdI FI_CORR_PRINT or SD billing output enhancement to pull payable data.

entry.title: Ready, Set, Go! Jump-start complex Collaboration Scenarios with Start Forms
entry.content:
Manually creating Collaborations in SAP Integrated Product Development (IPD) often requires several steps: creating the Collaboration itself, adding Reference Objects and Participants, starting Workflows, and more. Public APIs let you automate these steps. By invoking those APIs from a Process in SAP Build Process Automation - triggered by a Start Form - you can deliver an app-like experience to users inside SAP Build Work Zone.

This post shows how to provide dedicated Start Form apps for common IPD Collaboration scenarios. The main steps are:

  • Configure the Collaboration Type.
  • Design the Process and Start Form.
  • Add the Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone.

Configure the Collaboration Type

Create a Collaboration Type that maps to your business needs. Define a Status Profile, add Reference Objects, and attach Workflows. Using APIs to create Collaborations imposes no extra requirements.

Configure Collaboration

 

Design the Process and Start Form

Make sure that you have imported all required Actions for SAP Integrated Product Development Collaboration from SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Create a new Process in SAP Build Process Automation and design a Form as Trigger for the Process.

Start Form Designer

Add the Actions you need based on the Collaboration properties you want to set. In our example:

  1. Create a new Collaboration.
  2. Add a Participant.
  3. Add a Reference Object.
  4. Optionally start a Workflow (based on a user choice).

There are no tasks that require user interaction in this example. Of course, you can use all features provided by SAP Build Process Automation.

Process Design

Add Start Form to SAP Build Work Zone

Create a local copy of the Process Trigger App and provide the Launchpad Configuration Parameters of your deployed Process. Add this to your site and apply the required authorizations. The form will become visible as separate tile.

Start Form in SAP Build Work Zone

When users click the tile, the Start Form appears. 

Start Form

After they complete required fields and submit, the Process invokes the APIs to create the Collaboration, add the Reference Object and Participant, and start the Workflow if requested. The collaboration is ready within seconds and contains all necessary data for users to begin work.

Ready to use Collaboration

Summary

Start Forms are an efficient way to expose frequently used Collaboration setups to end users. By leveraging custom Processes, you can enrich user input with external data, add validations, and improve data quality and the overall experience - enabling smoother, faster collaboration.

entry.title: SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook (Part 6)
entry.content:
Integrating SAP EHS Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side - Guidebook

Part 6: Summary & Outlook

Table of Contents:

  • 1. Summary
  • 2. Benefits & Pitfalls
  • 2.1 Benefits
  • 2.2 Pitfalls
  • 2.3 Summary of Benefits & Pitfalls
  • 3. Outlook
  • 4. Engage with Us

Related Content:

Below is an overview of the planned blog series – each post focusing on a specific integration topic. Once published, the titles will be linked for direct access:

Integrating SAP EHS in the Public Cloud: Extending Your Existing Landscape Side-by-Side – Guidebook

Part 1: Introduction & OverviewLink
Part 2: Integration of Employees from SAP SuccessFactorsLink
Part 3: Integration of Business Partners & Material from SAP Master Data Governance (MDG)Link
Part 4: Integration of Functional Locations & Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise SystemLink
Part 5: Extensibility Scenarios & Further ImplementationLink
Part 6: Summary & OutlookLink

 

1. Summary

 

In this blog series, we shared our hands-on experience from multiple SAP EHS Public Cloud projects that were implemented in a hybrid, side-by-side landscape. Across Parts 1 to 5, we covered the integration of Employees, Business Partners, Materials, Functional Locations, and Equipment, as well as practical extensibility scenarios from real customer use cases.

What became very clear throughout these projects is that SAP EHS Public Cloud works best when three things come together:

  • Consistent master data,
  • Standardized integration content,
  • And a disciplined clean-core extensibility strategy.

In practice, we saw that missing or inconsistent master data was the most common root cause for broken end-to-end EHS processes (far more critical than any technical limitation). Once HR data, business partners, materials and assets were properly aligned across systems, incident reporting, emissions calculations, and follow-up processes became significantly more stable and transparent.

Another key learning was that standard communication scenarios and scope items save a tremendous amount of time and risk. Whenever we were able to rely on delivered content instead of custom interfaces, implementation effort, testing effort, and long-term maintenance were reduced noticeably.

Finally, extensibility played an important role in every single project. While most requirements could be solved using in-app Key User Extensibility, it was essential to define clear governance early on to avoid country-specific deviations and long-term technical debt.

This final part summarizes the key benefits and pitfalls we repeatedly encountered and shares our outlook on how SAP EHS in the Public Cloud will continue to evolve based on what we see today in real projects.

 

2. Benefits & Pitfalls

Integrating SAP EHS as part of a hybrid SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud landscape delivers strong business value but it also introduces architectural and organizational challenges that need to be managed carefully. In this chapter, we summarize the most important benefits and pitfalls we encountered across different customer projects.

2.1 Benefits

Fast Access to Innovation through Public Cloud Releases & AI

One of the strongest benefits we experienced in our projects was the direct access to new EHS functionality without classical upgrade projects. Unlike on-premise systems with long release cycles, customers benefit immediately from:

  • Regular Public Cloud releases and micro deliveries
  • Fast availability of new EHS features and regulatory content
  • Immediate access to SAP’s latest AI-driven innovations in EHS scenarios

This had a noticeable impact on time-to-value. Instead of waiting months for technical upgrades, functional improvements became available continuously. For several customers, this was also the first time AI-supported features in the EHS context could be evaluated productively.

Data Consistency and Compliance

A unified master data landscape turned out to be one of the biggest success factors across all projects. By integrating:

  • Employee data from SAP SuccessFactors
  • Business Partners & Materials from SAP MDG
  • Functional Locations and Equipment from SAP S/4HANA On-Premise

We ensured that EHS processes consistently relied on harmonized and validated master data. In practice, this was essential for:

  • Accurate incident reporting,
  • Reliable emissions calculations,
  • Correct assignment of responsibilities and workflows,
  • Audit-proof regulatory documentation.

Where master data was incomplete or inconsistent, downstream EHS processes were immediately affected.

Hybrid Architecture without Disruption

The side-by-side approach allowed customers to adopt EHS innovations in the Public Cloud without shutting down their existing on-premise environments. This enabled:

  • Gradual modernization instead of big-bang migrations,
  • Reduced transformation risk,
  • Protection of critical operational processes.

From a project perspective, this phased approach proved to be far more controllable than technical full-system replacements.

Standardized Interfaces and Scope Items

Whenever we could rely on standard SAP communication scenarios and scope items, the implantation became significantly faster and more stable. Examples include:

  • SAP_COM_0001, 0008, 0009, 0395
  • EHS scope items such as 3FP (Incident Management), 4XD (Emissions Management), and 54A (Health & Safety Management)

These accelerators reduced custom development effort, simplified testing, and aligned customer landscapes with SAP best practices.

Scalability and Future Readiness

The event-driven and API-first architecture of the Public Cloud supported scalable growth across all projects. Typical examples were:

  • Near real-time updated via SAP Integration Suite and Event Mesh,
  • Flexible replication cycles for HR and MDG data,
  • Cloud-native extensibility for future EHS enhancements.

This ensured that the technical foundation remained adaptable as regulatory and sustainability requirements continued to evolve.

Extensibility for Business and Regulatory Needs

Across all customers, extensibility was required mainly for country-specific regulations, additional validations, or customer-specific reporting. In most cases, these requirements could be fulfilled using Key User (In-App) Extensibility, without breaking the clean core. This allowed customers to remain upgrade-stable while still meeting local compliance needs.

2.2 Pitfalls

Despite the strong benefits, several recurring challenges also appeared in almost every project.

System Landscape Complexity

Hybrid landscapes naturally involve multiple systems: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, SAP MDG, SAP SuccessFactors, and SAP BTP / Integration Suite. Without clear integration ownership, defined interface responsibilities, and coordinated technical design, landscapes quickly became difficult to operate and monitor.

Dependency on Master Data Quality

EHS processes are extremely sensitive to master data issues. We repeatedly saw how missing materials, outdated organizational requirements, or incorrect functional locations immediately blocked emissions calculations, risk assessments, and incident follow-ups. High master data quality is mandatory.

Custom Development Where Standard Content Is Missing

For some integration scenarios, especially Plant Maintenance integration for Functional Location and Equipment, custom iFlows were still required. This introduced additional development effort, higher testing effort, and long-term maintenance overhead.

Monitoring Challenges

End-to-end monitoring must cover:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud application logs
  • SAP S/4HANA On-Premise applications logs
  • SAP Master Data Governance application logs
  • SAP SuccessFactors message monitoring
  • SAP Integration Suite / iFlow monitoring

In several projects, missing monitoring initially led to delayed error detection and avoidable compliance risks.

Value Mapping and Harmonization

Incorrect or inconsistent value mappings between systems repeatedly caused replication failures. Early harmonization of organizational units, material types, equipment categories proved to be critical.

Validation of Services and Scope Items

Missing API activations or scope item assignments (e.g., API_EQUIPMENT or API_FUNCTIONALLOCATION) frequently caused delays late in the project. Early validation of all required services became a key project success factor.

Governance and Limitations of Extensibility

Extensibility offers flexibility but without governance it quickly leads to:

  • Diverging country solutions,
  • Misaligned business logic
  • And long-term technical debt.

Additionally, Developer Extensibility is still limited to released APIs and BAdIs, which means that not every requirement can be solved purely with custom logic.

2.3 Summary of Benefits & Pitfalls

A successful EHS Public Cloud implementation balances the strengths of standardized integration content and clean-core extensibility with disciplined data governance and architectural planning. Organizations that manage this balance effectively can unlock the full potential of SAP EHS – enabling safe, compliant, and scalable EHS operations across the enterprise.

 

3. Outlook

Based on what we observe across current customer projects and SAP’s latest roadmap updates, SAP EHS in the Public Cloud is clearly evolving from a standalone compliance solution toward a central digital backbone for safety, risk, and environmental governance.

Many customers are already productive with core EHS scenarios today. At the same time, the functional scope continues to expand with each Public Cloud release. We see a strong move toward more standardized business content, broader regulatory coverage, and deeper support for environmental and sustainability-driven processes. As a result, future implementations will increasingly rely on configuration rather than custom development which significantly reduces implementation and upgrade effort.

Extensibility will nevertheless remain a key success factor. From our project experience, SAP is steadily increasing both the number and the quality of released APIs and cloud-compliant BAdIs. This allows customers to address local regulatory requirements and  compliant-specific validation logic in a clean-core compatible way. Especially Key User Extensibility is becoming more powerful, enabling business-driven adjustments without technical development.

In parallel, SAP BTP is gaining further importance for advanced EHS use cases. While this blog series focused on On-Stack Extensibility, we already see growing demand for advanced analytics and dashboards, cross-system workflow automation, and IoT-based hazard detection and emissions monitoring. These scenarios clearly go beyond standard transactional processing and position SAP BTP as a natural complement to SAP EHS in complex enterprise landscapes.

Another major trend we observe is the increasing convergence of EHS and sustainability. Environmental compliance, emissions management, and sustainability reporting are becoming tightly connected. From a solution perspective, this strengthens the integration between SAP EHS, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and SAP Sustainability Control Tower. Customers will benefit from more consistent emissions data, integrated compliance reporting, and harmonized master data across production, procurement, and asset management.

For customers, these developments reinforce one central message from our project work: Early architectural discipline pays off. Organizations that invest early in clean-core principles, standardized integration content, high master data quality, and clear extensibility governance are best positioned to benefit from future SAP innovations.

 

4. Engage with Us

To follow the series, make sure to subscribe to the SAP EHS Public Cloud blog tag.

We welcome your thoughts and feedback in the comments!

Acknowledgements

This blog post series is the result of close collaboration within our EHS implementation team. I would like to express my sincere appreciation to my colleagues, whose expertise, insights, and project experience significantly contributed to the depth and quality of this guide.

A special thank you goes to:

  • @Westphal 
  • @qkroiss 
  • @asutoshmaharana2326 
  • @kanwal_singh
  • @Suraj_Ashray1 

Their contributions were instrumental in shaping the content of this blog post. I am truly grateful for their collaborations and support.

entry.title: Re: How can I to Delete a Subcontracting MRP area?
entry.content:
Hi Jez,

The issue you're experiencing with deleting type 3 (subcontracting) MRP areas is a known problem in S/4HANA systems. The error "It is not allowed to delete MRP areas that are valid" occurs because the system has specific requirements for properly removing subcontracting MRP areas that differ from standard location-based MRP areas.

Root Cause and Solution

This is a documented issue that requires implementing SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS2 or applying the correction instruction for SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS1 [1]. The problem stems from system validation logic that prevents deletion of subcontracting MRP areas even when all apparent dependencies have been removed.

Step-by-Step Resolution Process

1. Verify System Prerequisites

  • Ensure you're running SAP S/4HANA OP2023 FPS2 or have applied the correction instruction for FPS1
  • Note that there is no correction instruction available for the base SAP S/4HANA OP2023 release [1]

2. Complete Data Cleanup Process

Since you've already performed most cleanup steps, verify the following sequence:

Material Master Cleanup:

  • Set deletion indicators for all MRP area assignments in MM02 [2]
  • Ensure all materials have the deletion flag set specifically for the MRP area view
  • Run transaction MDDIBE to reorganize MRP data
  • Execute report YMRPAREO to clean up remaining MRP area data [2]

Stock and Planning Element Verification:

  • Confirm complete removal of all stock from the subcontracting location
  • Verify no active MRP elements (planned orders, purchase requisitions) reference the MRP area
  • Check for any remaining consumption or forecast data

3. Alternative Approach for Persistent Issues

If the standard cleanup doesn't work, consider this approach based on SAP community recommendations [3]:

  1. Temporarily recreate the MRP area in customizing if it was previously deleted
  2. Re-establish material assignments to the MRP area
  3. Properly set deletion flags for all material assignments
  4. Run YMRPAREO report to systematically remove all dependent data [3]
  5. Attempt deletion through OMIZB again

4. Use Correct Transaction Code

Ensure you're using OMIZB (non-transport relevant) rather than OMIZA for production system changes [4]. OMIZB is specifically designed for local customizing changes without transport requirements.

Important Considerations

Data Safety: The YMRPAREO report permanently deletes MRP area data and should be used with extreme caution. SAP recommends using it only in test systems and assumes no responsibility for side effects [2].

Production Systems: For production environments, ensure you have proper change management procedures in place and consider the impact on ongoing operations.

Advanced Planning Integration: If your materials are marked as Advanced Planning relevant, additional steps may be required to properly phase out the MRP areas from PP/DS planning [5].

** Generated using "Joule for consultant"

Best regards,Naveen

entry.title: Send the BGRFC Queue in error ABAP code
entry.content:
Hello All,

I have a program that executes parallel tasks within the same system using bgRFC along with multiple qRFC queues. Each queue processes tasks sequentially, and once the first queue completes, it triggers the next one.

During the execution of the subsequent queue, we perform a custom validation. If this validation fails, we want to return that queue so the user can process the queue manually . To achieve this, we introduced a WAIT statement when the check fails. This does send the queue into error status as expected, but it also results in system dumps.

Is there an alternative approach to handle this scenario without causing dumps?

There are very limited discussions available on bgRFC, and the official documentation also lacks detailed information in some areas. I hope this discussion can help others facing similar challenges. Please note that I’m not entirely sure whether the classes I’m using are officially supported by SAP or if my current approach is the best practice so all suggestions and corrections are most welcome.

Thank you for reading, and I look forward to your comments.

entry.title: Re: Issue with MultiInput Not Accepting Multiple Values i...

We faced similar issue a couple of weeks ago.

The following approach might be used to resolve the issue:

- view:

<MultiInput id="multiInput1" showSuggestion="false" showValueHelp="false"/>

- controller:

const oMultiInput1 = this.getView().byId('multiInput1');

oMultiInput1.addValidator(function(oEvent) {   

    return new sap.m.Token({ key: oEvent.text, text: oEvent.text });

});

 

Key point is to add validator to the MultiInput contol.

Hope this post will help you to eliminate the issue.

entry.title: Re: Change template in the app Display G/L Account Balances

Hi,

Please use ' "Split Cells with Multiple Values" Feature

  1. Navigate to your desired report (e.g., Display G/L Account Balance)

entry.title: Re: #CoE#GZHX Batch Operation in Change Billing Documents...
entry.content:
Hi Julia,

Please consider following Available Options:

Option 1: Manage Billing Documents App Enhancement

  • Currently works only for standard format billing documents
  • May require document format standardization or configuration adjustments
  • Limited by current SAP standard functionality scope

Implementation Steps

  • Review current billing document formats and identify which can be processed through the standard app
  • Configure automatic posting settings in "Create Billing Documents" app to enable batch processing
  • Establish user access and training for the Manage Billing Documents app workflow

Option 2: API-Based Custom Solution

  • Technical Approach Leverage the API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV service which supports batch operations for billing document processing
  • Develop custom Fiori app or integration solution using OData batch requests
  • Similar approach used successfully for mass PDF downloads can be adapted for release operations

Option 3: Process Automation Solutions

BR, Yong

entry.title: Re: Standard Story report not picking all employees despite no filter on the query ?
entry.content:
Hello Imzei,    

The data in story depends on 2 things,  

  • Permissions and target population
  • Query design   

Since you have confirmed the data is visible when a story is manually created, here the data could be restricted based on the joins used in query, if an inner join is used and the user doesn't have any data maintained for table 2, then the user will not show up in the report.


Another reason could be due to difference in the object configurations across the instance the standard story was designed on and the instance you are currently using , as indicated in https://me.sap.com/notes/3165289/E

If the reports output remains inconsistent for the same user after validating the configuration and object level filters, you can reach out to SAP Support for further assistance.

Thanks,
Ananya

entry.title: Re: S4 GR - Specific Reporting View
entry.content:
Hi Frank,

You have a couple of options:

1)

You have the possibility to just create a second consolidation group just holding these 2 consolidation units. You will not be required to copy data between versions. You just need to run the consolidation monitor eliminations for this group. If you are using the new consolidation monitor in Public Cloud this is easy. Your eliminations will be between those 2 cons.units and rest will be treated as external.

2)

You can use the hierarchy eliminations for consolidation units. Create an hierarchy with these 2 consolidation units under 1 hierarchy note. You can familiarize yourself with cases in SAP help page: 

Case 1: Hierarchical and Matrix Consolidations | SAP Help Portal 

Case 2: Combining Consolidation Group and Hierarchies​ | SAP Help Portal

3)

If you will keep data separate in versions, create a simulation versions on top of your standard version with a different special version for consolidation group structure. Have the version to be executed automatic when the main version is executed. This will give you a similar approach as 1 but without needing to execute consolidation twice. Only the delta values from your main versions is stored. SAP help also have a good explanation on version stack:  Version Stack | SAP Help Portal

Hope one of these options can help you forward.

Br

Martin Jul

entry.title: ML currency change during migration ( Bluefield)
entry.content:
HI Experts,

Could you please help with below query,

Its a S/4HANA migration (blue field) project. In ECC the currency set up is 10,30 and 40. Same  has been assigned to ML currency as well.

OB22

ML currency

in S/4HANA client need to bring group valuation with group currency. So currency type 31 need to bring in.

My questions

1) Whether I can change the ML currency from 10,30, 40 to 10, 30,31 in S/4HANA. If yes, any impact to the ML values during data migration.

2) Any insights to data copying to S/4HANA would be really helpful in above case

entry.title: Re: How to Combine Multiple MRP Purchase Proposals and Ap...
entry.content:
Good day @kuroneko96 

Thank you for your question.

Answer to your question 1:

In public cloud, the system evaluates minimum lot size for each procurement proposal. This behaviour is described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/2bba750d1e124e1ea2a039bb1cd9b6c5/dca5bb53707db44ce10000000a174cb4.html?locale=en-US

So, for you to have A+B combined and then checked against the minimum lot size, you have to use a period lot-sizing procedure. This will ensure both of your requirements fall into one single lot period. The system then sums A+B and if necessary, it will increase to the minimum. Basically, there is no standard option that allows you to apply a minimum lot size across multiple periods or to arbitrarily combine different requirements beyond the lot-sizing logic in public cloud.

Answer to your question 2:

For you to trace which demands a PO covers, the public cloud does not show all MRP elements directly in the PO.  You should use MRP apps for pegging and optionally the Requirement Tracking Number

plus the Display Documents by Tracking Number app for reporting.

You can find more information on that through this link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/9210deb79b8a4076ac01d9455388cf63.html?locale=en-US

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Contribution Margin Forecast with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
MANAGEMENT SUMMARY

This blog demonstrates how SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) can be used to implement a contribution margin forecast, which serves companies as a substantial controlling tool to steer financial results in the short- and medium-term. Combining SAC Planning with Datasphere (“Seamless Planning”) allows for (near) real-time usage of actual data from SAP BW to extrapolate the variable cost component of the contribution margin, while SAC Planning is used to forecast the revenue component and report on the resulting KPIs.  The combination of the actual and planning data happens without the need for redundant data replication. Furthermore, this blog will briefly touch on how BDC can be leveraged to enhance this use case through a comprehensive path for BW modernization, the re-use of SAP-managed data products, and the application of advanced machine learning methods for forecasting.

RECAP

Before continue reading it is recommended to familiarize with the following preceding blog posts to properly understand the fundamentals:  

  • The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering puts this blog post into perspective of a comprehensive blog series that aims to demonstrate the business value add of SAP BDC.
  • Real-time steering with LIVE planning uncovers the "Seamless Planning" paradigm (which is the key enabler for below-described use case) and illustrates a practical end-to-end use case that leverages External Live Versions, our latest innovation in context of Seamless Planning.

MOTIVATION AND USE CASE

The motivation of this blog is to demonstrate a tangible implementation example for how BDC can be leveraged to enable effective and efficient business steering. The demonstrated use case is a contribution margin forecast which estimates future revenues and variable costs, calculating expected contribution margins over time. The contribution margin is particularly relevant for financial steering because fixed costs are, by definition, largely unchangeable in the short- and medium-term. Therefore, if a company aspires to impact financial results, management’s primary focus and opportunity for action resides in maximizing the contribution margin. In essence, the contribution margin is calculated by subtracting variable costs from revenues, with the remainder – that is, the contribution margin – available to cover fixed costs. The levers that management can actively influence on a regular basis are:

Picture 1: Calculation schema for Contribution Margin

Such a contribution margin forecast can be implemented in an innovative fashion leveraging the Seamless Planning capability within BDC as explained in the following paragraph.

IMPLEMENTATION

Considering the above-described contribution margin levers, we are using the following BDC components for the corresponding implementation.

A SAC Story on top of a SAC Planning model is used to enter sales volume forecast and pricing assumptions (1). Upon publishing (2) the forecasted values (volumes, prices) are directly persisted within Datasphere (“Seamless Planning”).

Picture 2: SAC frontend for revenue forecastDatasphere is used to acquire and model total actual variable costs and sales volumes based on SAP BW in our example (3) (or any other compatible and relevant source system). Note that actual sales volumes are acquired to allow the calculation of volume-weighted actual variable costs per unit in a later step. A union view (4) within Datasphere combines the forecasted sales volumes and prices (as provided via the SAC Planning frontend) with the actual sales volumes and variable costs (as acquired from SAP BW).

Picture 3: Data lineage within Datasphere

In an Analytic Model (5) on top of the union view the relevant KPIs consisting of both forecast and actual data are calculated:

Forecasted revenues: Restricted measures filter on forecasted volumes and prices originating from the SAC planning model. A calculated measure multiplies these two measures to derive the forecasted revenue [forecasted revenues = forecasted sales volumes * price assumption].

Extrapolated variable costs: Restricted measures filter on actual volumes and total manufacturing costs originating from SAP BW. These measures are cumulated over the actual time horizon as selected per prompt (6). A calculated measure divides cumulated costs by cumulated volumes to derive the volume-weighted average costs per unit [weighted-average costs per unit = cumulated actual costs/cumulated actual sales volumes]. Note that this measure is kept constant over the time dimension to allow applicability to any forecast months (see below).

Expected contribution margin: A calculated measure extrapolates the actual variable costs by multiplying the volume-weighted actuals costs per unit (see above) with the forecasted sales volumes [extrapolated variable costs = weighted-average actuals costs per unit * forecasted sales volumes]. A calculated measure subtracts extrapolated variable costs from forecasted revenues to finally derive the contribution margin [contribution margin forecast = forecasted revenues -  extrapolated variable costs].

Picture 4: Analytic Model within Datasphere A SAC Story on top the Analytic Model is used to steer the prompt for the weighted-average actual variable costs (6) and display the results -- that is, the weighted-average variable costs (left chart) and the derived contribution margin (right table) (7).

Picture 5: SAC frontend for analysis The following diagram summarizes the architecture and data flow at a glance.

Picture 6: Seamless Planning architecture

It is now worthwhile looking at the unique highlights of the above-described setup. First, Seamless Planning within BDC combines "best of both worlds": SAC planning and reporting capabilities with Datasphere ETL and modeling capabilities. Second, SAC planning model entries are directly exposed within Datasphere upon publishing without the need for redundant data replication. Third, it would be generally feasible to access the actual variable costs virtually (as opposed to replicated), thus combining planning with actual data in real-time. However, note that regular snapshots (near real-time) of the actual data can be required for high-performant dashboards. Forth, the prompt to dynamically steer the time range for the weighted-average actual variable costs allows end users to sort of “smoothen” the data over time (when choosing a longer range) versus emphasizing more recent months to reflect latest changes in cost structures etc. Lastly, given the completely automated retrieval of the variable costs part of the calculation, end users only need to manually update the expected sales volumes and price assumptions. This allows for a fast forecast process with a high frequency (e.g., monthly rolling forecast) which is highly relevant in today’s dynamic market environment.

POSSIBLE ENHANCEMENTS

In the above-described implementation setup actual data is being acquired from an SAP BW system via standard data acquisition means in Datasphere (remote tables, real-time replication, etc.). However, for SAP BW systems (both BW/4 and on HANA) BDC opens up the path for comprehensive BW modernization through means of the Data Product Generator (please see this blog for further details).

Furthermore, the use case could be enriched with SAP-managed data products derived from an S/4 PCE system as part of a BDC formation. For instance, if the contribution margin forecast should be integrated into a broader plan/actual reporting solution, the relevant actuals could be built upon SAP-managed data products serving as significant accelerators given that the complete data orchestration is handled by SAP. You could directly start modeling within Datasphere and combine the forecast data with the actual data based on the SAP-managed data products. A detailed blog discussing how you can leverage data products in the context of planning will follow.

Finally, for more advanced forecasting techniques you could leverage SAP Databricks as part of the BDC formation. Imagine that instead of the manually provided sales volume forecast as in the above example you would generate such a forecast by means of statistical methods such as time series forecasting.

Picture 7: Enhancement options with BDC

SUMMARY AND CALL TO ACTION

A contribution margin forecast allows companies to proactively steer financial results and can therefore be considered a crucial controlling instrument. SAP BDC enables an innovative implementation approach with clear benefits such as rapid, high-frequency forecasts through automated calculation of variable costs and replication-free, (near) real time combination of actual and planning data. Besides that, SAP BDC opens up the path for comprehensive BW modernization, thus allowing you to follow parallel streams: Implementation of innovative use cases while modernizing your SAP BW.  Sounds like a plan to you? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

entry.title: Advanced ABAP programming syntax
entry.content:
This blog is to provide new ABAP programming syntax along with some use case to ease and save development time of beginners and experienced professional who is looking for Advanced ABAP programming.

Many times, we come across a scenario where we have to bring data from different internal tables. As per traditional ABAP we use to loop the main internal table and then use READ TABLE statement for processing each field value. 

Scenario: An internal table contains data passed from an API, we need to validate the data like check if Material, plant & storage location is valid or invalid from different value tables like T001W, T001L MARA etc

Old syntax: 

New Syntax:

FOR keyword is used for main LOOP--ENDLOOP and LET---VALUE keyword allows you to declare work area for different Internal table like READ STATEMENTS and COND.. WHEN..THEN keyword will allow you to set the conditions.

Scenario: Many times, we need to append values to the internal table already holding some records then we have to use the BASE keyword.

Scenario: To create Range table from entries of different internal table

Scenario: To pass entries from one internal table to another based on filtering using FILTER keyword. Note: Internal table should be of SORTED or HASHED table type with KEY.

To calculate sum in internal table we use REDUCE statement

Output: Total Salary: 39000

Scenario: GROUP BY statement is used to group the data like for example Order containing multiple item details and we want to pass each order detail to some BAPI for data update.

Hope it helps the members looking for quick info on Advanced ABAP programming.

Next time will try to cover the CDS entities and RAP ABAP blogs. Till then happy coding 🙂

entry.title: Streamlining Manufacturing Logistics with clean core API’s
entry.content:
In the rapidly moving world of manufacturing logistics, agility and minimizing complexity is crucial. SAP S/4HANA for Manufacturing Logistics, with its latest API updates, is supporting this pace:

  • Clean Core Approach:
    • Separates extensions and integrations from core processes
    • Reduces total cost of ownership (TCO) and improves agility
    • Enables integration with analytics and cloud services

 

  • Why?
    • Faster decision-making and simpler upgrades
    • Better operational efficiency and long-term resilience
    • Continuous business value delivery

The updated APIs fully align with our Clean Core principles, offering robust solutions that improve integration, automation, and competitiveness. These innovations can genuinely transform how you run your manufacturing logistics operations.

Lets double click into it!

We delivered three API’s to run Route Trains and Shuttles, including an API to get access to your Shuttle configurations.

 

Route Train Operations:

The route train enhances logistics by handling not only production supply but also tasks like inbound processes and various replenishment processes, ensuring efficient, effective and flexible operations.

Streamline your logistics with Route Train Operations (A2X)! This powerful API integrates external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes in warehouses and production environments. Here’s what makes it a must-have:

  • Effortless Warehouse Validation: Log on or off warehouse resources and verify their readiness with ease.
  • Simplified Recovery Case Checks: Stay informed about the recovery status of your warehouse resources.
  • Streamlined Tour Management: Create system-guided tours to simplify loading and unloading workflows.
  • Smart Handling of Units (HUs): Validate, load, or remove HUs during tours seamlessly and efficiently.
  • Pause or Continue Operations: Flexibly interrupt or resume loading/unloading workflows whenever needed.
  • Customizable Tour Stops: Skip, transfer, or tailor stops by stop type (e.g., PSA or Transfer Point) to match your requirements.
  • Instant Storage Bin Insights: Check which bins are empty for smarter space utilization.
  • Complete Unloading Capability: Unload all handling units quickly and without issue.
  • Detailed Metadata Access: Retrieve vital data on loading, unloading, tour stops, and handling unit compositions for complete control.

Whether you’re optimizing warehouse workflows or streamlining production logistics, the Route Train Operations API is here to improve efficiency.

 

 

 

Shuttle Operations:

The shuttle simplifies the movement of goods between locations, like from a production plant to a shipping warehouse, using trucks, trains, or other transportation, while combining storage and warehouse processes under one EWM warehouse number, without needing separate inbound or outbound deliveries.

Simplify your shuttle logistics with Shuttle Operator (A2X)!

This API integrates external applications to optimize loading and unloading processes for shuttles in manufacturing and warehouse environments. Here’s how it makes operations seamless:

  • Create New Shuttles with Ease: Set up new shuttles to streamline transportation in just a few steps.
  • Retrieve Location or Carrier Information: Access key information about your shuttle whenever needed.
  • Add or Remove Loading/Unloading Points: Gain full control by easily adding or removing points for logistics flexibility.
  • Smart Handling Unit (HU) Operations: Load, unload, or transfer multiple HUs (or Freight Units) to and from shuttles without a hitch.
  • Access Detailed Consignment and Cargo Data: Read consignment information to ensure accuracy in handling cargo.
  • Update Shuttle Status: Choose from critical status options like "Start loading," "Start unloading," or "Complete," ensuring workflow alignment.
  • Manage Seals for Freight Security: View, create, or remove seals on shuttles for better security and compliance management.
  • Gain Metadata Insights: Retrieve essential service metadata for enhanced logistics visibility.

From efficient shuttle creation to secure handling of cargo, Shuttle Operator (A2X) equips you with everything needed to run smooth and reliable transportation operations. Try it now and take control of your logistics!

 

 

 

Shuttle configurations:

Optimize your shuttle logistics configuration with Shuttle Configuration (A2X)! This API is designed to enhance shuttle loading and unloading workflows by providing essential transport and carrier data. Here’s how it can help you stay ahead:

  • Retrieve Transport Details for Shuttles: Access specific information on the means of transport for shuttle logistics, making planning and tracking effortless.
  • Access Carrier Information: Instantly retrieve carrier details to ensure smooth coordination between vendors and logistics teams.

With Shuttle Configuration (A2X), you gain quick access to essential configuration data, laying the foundation for efficient shuttle operations. Ready to integrate smarter workflows into your logistics? Try it today!

 

 

 

What’s Possible with Manufacturing Logistics APIs

Clean Core APIs enable you to build innovative and custom solutions for logistics and warehouse management by leveraging SAP’s modern architecture. From SDK apps, to MDK Apps, providing modern FIORI apps and integrate automation, here's what you can achieve:

  • Build Custom Native Apps: Design tailored Android or iOS apps for seamless consumer grad User Experience 

     

 

  • Create SAP Fiori/UI5 Applications: Develop SAP-based applications for guided loading/unloading processes and workflow tracking with responsive designs.
  • Integrate External Applications or Robotics: Connect Manufacturing Logistics APIs with third-party tools for transportation management or warehouse systems.

 

  • Automate Operational Workflows: Streamline processes like shuttle configuration updates, tour adjustments, and metadata retrieval with API-driven automation.

 

  • Enable Cross-Platform Solutions: Develop solutions that work across web, desktop, tablets, and mobile devices, ensuring maximum flexibility.

These APIs empower your teams to innovate while keeping the SAP core clean, scalable, and future-proof.

Additional Information:

entry.title: Bookmark - How to estimate your costs using Cost Estimator to track your Finops
entry.content:
Why Cost Estimation on SAP BTP Matters

SAP BTP offers flexibility and scalability, but without proper cost visibility, you risk:

  • Budget overruns
  • Unplanned expenses
  • Difficulty aligning IT spend with business goals

Cost estimation ensures you can plan ahead, optimize usage, and stay compliant with financial governance.

How It Supports FinOps

FinOps is about visibility, accountability, and optimization. The Cost Estimator helps by:

  • Providing accurate cost projections for SAP BTP services
  • Allowing scenario planning for scaling workloads
  • Supporting continuous cost monitoring and optimization

Reference :

  • The FinOps Foundation: https://www.finops.org/

What is the SAP BTP Cost Estimator?

The SAP BTP Cost Estimator is a tool that helps you:

  • Simulate service usage across different BTP components
  • Forecast monthly and annual costs based on your planned consumption
  • Compare pricing models (subscription vs. consumption-based)

This tool is essential for FinOps teams, enabling transparency and collaboration between finance and engineering.

SAP BTP FinOps tool

  • 📄 Blog introducing the tool: BTP FinOps: Keeping Track of Your Credits
  • 🚀 Discovery Center Mission to start: Mission 4489
  • 🔧 Github project with source code: SAP-samples: btp-resource-consumption-monitor
  • 🎥 Installation Video step-by-step: YouTube

Past

SAP BTP FinOps webinars

  • Webinar 13 March 2025 (DSAG + SUGEN) [introduction]: 📄 Invitation and 🎥 Recording
  • Webinar 12 March 2025 (SAP BTP Garage) [technical]: 📄 Invitation and 🎥 Recording
  • Webinar 16 December 2024 [introduction]: 🎥 Recording

Steps to Estimate Your SAP BTP Costs

  1. Identify Your Services
    List the SAP BTP services you plan to use (e.g., SAP Integration Suite, SAP HANA Cloud).

  2. Access the SAP BTP Cost Estimator
    Navigate to the SAP BTP Cost Estimator in the SAP Discovery Center.

  3. Configure Your Usage

    • Select your region and environment.
    • Input expected usage metrics (e.g., number of API calls, storage size, compute units).

  4. Review the Estimate
    Analyze projected monthly and yearly costs. Look for optimization opportunities like reserved capacity or bundled services.

  5. Track and Adjust
    Compare actual costs in the SAP BTP Cockpit with your estimates. Use this feedback to refine future forecasts.

List of Cost Estimator

SAP HANA Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator
https://hcsizingestimator.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/sap/hana/estimator/index.html 

SAP Cloud Logging Capacity Unit Estimator

https://sap-cloud-logging-estimator.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com
SAP Datasphere Capacity Unit Estimatorhttps://dwc-pricing-calculator-sac-saceu10.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/index.html 
SAP Business Data Cloud Capacity Unit Estimator
https://datasphere-estimator-sac-sacus10.cfapps.us10.hana.ondemand.com/ 

SAP Kyma runtime Cost Estimator

https://kyma-project.github.io/price-calculator/ 
SAP AI Core Cost Calculator https://ai-core-calculator.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/uimodule/index.html 

SAP Build Code Capacity Unit Calculator

https://build-code-calculator.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/ 

 SAP Build Process Automation, document understanding and task mining add-on by UiPath

https://spa-prod-eu-spa-capacity-unit-estimator.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ 

All other BTP Services

 SAP BTP Serviceshttps://discovery-center.cloud.sap/estimator 

 

Best Practices for SAP BTP FinOps

  • Run estimates before deploying new services.
  • Include all components—integration, database, networking—to avoid hidden costs.
  • Collaborate with finance teams to align estimates with budget cycles.
  • Leverage SAP Discovery Center missions for guidance on cost optimization.

entry.title: Re: How to re-populate external ID's of entities after a...
entry.content:
Pushing an object via DRFOUT (e.g., using S/4HANA) replicates the entire object, which leads to duplicates since both systems treat it as "new."
What you need is to only update the External ID, not recreate the entire object—this is exactly the scenario that External ID Mapping is built.

Here is the reason why
When replicating objects (like Accounts, Business Partners, etc.) from S/4HANA to Sales Cloud, the system generates a unique internal ID in the Sales Cloud.
Stores the originating S/4HANA ID as an External ID in the External ID Mapping table—regardless of whether the internal and external IDs match or differ.
The External ID Mapping allows the Sales Cloud to reference objects based on the source system’s ID, ensuring consistent integration.

It's also the foundation for confirmation messages that can travel back to S/4HANA, updating the source with the newly assigned internal ID in Sales Cloud.
A Business Partner is sent from SAP S/4HANA to the cloud CRM. The cloud CRM responds with the Confirmation Message back to SAP S/4HANA, which includes the cloud CRM’s business partner ID. SAP S/4HANA stores this ID in the Unified Key Management, which is the equivalent of the cloud CRM’s External ID Mapping. Therefore, SAP S/4HANA knows the ID of the business partner in SAP Sales and Service Cloud Version 2 and can send it along if needed.

entry.title: Re: #COE#DE01 Error Message: Cannot update or delete. Act...
entry.content: Hi, For error "Cannot update or delete. Actuals have been posted", please check following analyzing and solution. The core issue stems from SAP's data integrity protection mechanism. When actual hours are posted against a work package, the system locks certain modifications to prevent data inconsistency. In your case: Timing Mismatch: The significant gap between planned (Jan 2023) and staffed/actual periods (Feb 2024) creates a complex scenario Volume Discrepancy: 21 actual hours vs 1 planned/staffed hour indicates either under-planning or over-execution Historical Data Protection: The system prevents modifications that could invalidate posted actuals SAP Note Analysis SAP Note 2901254: While you noted this doesn't seem directly applicable, it actually provides key insight - the error occurs when changing work package duration where posting dates fall outside the new duration SAP Note 3646588: Specifically addresses this error in external staffing scenarios, confirming that redistribution of staffed hours can lead to zero-hour periods where actuals exist

entry.title: Re: Clarification Needed on Revised Cost Appearing Higher...
entry.content:
Good day @rohini_dutta21 

Thank you for your response. I will provide a summarised answer based solely on what you posted here.

Answer to your question 1:

In public cloud, Revised Costs and the percentage to which it is completed are designed as forecast values. Considering many business scenarios experience situations where cost exceed forecast, the logic is to legitimately allow you to exceed 100% of the original PO amount when expected costs are higher than the PO value. Therefore, it is a standard behaviour for the system to only generate a warning when you exceed the 100% based on that logic. It is not a bug you noticed during your testing.

Here you will find further details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/2e841bc5cbdd4d088141bd75fe4229ad.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/b578526760074a1f846a7168bc4000e9.html

Answer to your question 2:

No. There is no configuration that can turn this warning into a hard error or technically block revised costs when it exceeds 100% of the forecast. I am not aware of any BAdI or SSCUI that can either do that.

If your client’s goal is to achieve governance, the best practice is to use:

  • Workflow approval for purchase order accruals,
  • Threshold variants that force manual review for high-value items/PO and
  • Analytics that help them highlight cases where Revised Costs exceed PO value or when PoC goes above 100%

Have a look at these reference for more details:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0fa84c9d9c634132b7c4abb9ffdd8f06/92328b3f8d0141f3a3ad4df8e3fc2ca2.html?locale=en-US

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: STO BRASIL - Determinação direito fiscal ICMS
entry.content:
Olá,

preciso de ajuda com o seguinte cenário: estou realizando uma transferência com origem SP e destino SP, onde fiz a amarração do controle de cópia da minha remessa ao tipo de ordem de vendas e tipo de item ZTRF. Na J_1BSDICA, deixei o direito fiscal de ICMS vazio para esse tipo de item e o amarrei ao código de imposto I0 (com a ideia de que, uma vez vazio na J_1BSDICA, o sistema faria a sequência de acesso de MM para determinar a aba Brasil):

Em MM, determinei que o código de imposto I0 está amarrado ao IVA YS:

Desta forma, imaginei que a determinação do direito fiscal do ICMS seguiria a sequência BRLC, a qual está configurada desta maneira:

O ponto é, da forma com que imaginei a solução, uma exceção criada no grupo 15 por IVA (YS da minha transferência) e material seria relevante para determinação do direito fiscal na remessa. Porém a remessa está sendo criada com direito fiscal que está cadastrado no grupo 20:

Exceção criada no grupo 15 com IVA da transferência + material da operação:

Exceção criada no grupo 20 apenas com material:

Já rodei o programa J_1B_CBT_CONSIST e deletei registros de condições erradas. Já migrei as tabelas da J1BTAX, porém o erro persiste. Minha dúvida é: o que pode estar causando esse comportamento no sistema, de ignorar o grupo 15? Adicionalmente, se alguém tiver sugestões de como trabalhar com um único IVA na STO Brasil e resolver os impostos por exceções, estou aberto. Grato desde já!

entry.title: Trigger Cross-Entity Rule to delete hourly pay component and add base salary at the same time
entry.content:
Hi,

we have an issue with the Trigger Cross-Entity that is not working via import or interface (API) only when the record is updated manually.

  • Requirements

If the employee is from USA and already has a "Hourly rate"  (10Z1) Recurring Pay Component, it must be automatically deleted so that the "Base Salary" (10Z3) Recurring Pay Component can be accepted for recording.

 

  • Proposed solution

Using the Trigger Cross-Entity Rule scenario, the business rule was defined to delete the recurring pay component Hourly rate" (10Z1) in the Compensation Information.

This is a rule with the base object Compensation Information Model and it is added as an onSave rule to Compensation Information in Manage Business Configuration.

 

 

 

It works when manual update

 

But does not work with import:

 

Error: Only one Pay Component can be assigned with the value of ‘Used for Comp Planning’ as ‘COMP’ or ‘BOTH’. PayComponent Hourly rate already has this set.

And does not work with API:

 

2593172 - Error while uploading Pay Components: Only one Pay Component can be assigned with the value of Used for Comp Planning as COMP or BOTH

We cannot change the configuration of the pay components.

But even if the rule does not work with import and API even if the pay components configuration is changed – it is not deleting the Hourly Rate pay component:

 

 

We have tested also the following options but none of them worked:

1)      Scenario: Trigger Cross-Entity Rules

Base Object: Compensation Information Model

Event Type: onSave

Trigger Rules section: Compensation Information

 

2) Scenario: Trigger onSave Rules for HRIS Elements

Base Object:  Compensation Model

Event Type:  onSave

Trigger Rules section: Compensation Information

3) Scenario: Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements

             Base object: Compensation Model

             Event Type: onChange

             Trigger Rules section: under the Recurring Pay Components field

 

4)      Scenario: Trigger Cross-Entity Rules

             Base object: Compensation Model

             Event Type: onSave

             Trigger Rules section: under the Recurring Pay Components field

 

 

 

 

The issue: the configuration in the parameter  Used for Comp Planning  for the two components in Manage Organization, Pay and Job Structure is as follows

Pay Component Hourly rate (10Z1) Used for Comp Planning : Comp

Pay Component Base Salary (10Z3) Used for Comp Planning : Both

 

The business rule works when the data are being updated manually but it does not work when the data are sent via interface. We receive the following error message:

“Only one Pay Component can be assigned with the value of ?Used for Comp Planning? as ?COMP? or ?BOTH?. PayComponent Hourly rate already has this set.”

 

 

According to the information on the SAP Help Portal the cross entity rules are triggered based on changes made in the Take Action menu as well as the History UI. If these rules are configured as onSave rules, they will also be triggered during imports and API calls.

Common Problems for Business Rules in Employee Central | SAP Help Portal

 

 

Conclusions after thorough tests:

the cross entity business rule deletes Hourly rate (10Z1) pay component only when the record is entered manually  regardless of the configuration in the parameter  Used for Comp Planning  set to Comp or Both

And it does not deletes the pay component via import or API even if the configuration in the parameter  Used for Comp Planning  is disabled, but only adds a new pay component: Base salary (10Z3) although in the rule trace it says: "Successfully deleted 1 objects from collection 'payComponentRecurring'. Duration: 65 microseconds;

entry.title: Re: S4 Public Cloud Sales Reports Functionality
entry.content:
Dear @JuliaLu,

In Public Cloud customers usually do not need custom development to get solid Sales reporting.

The system ships with Embedded Analytics: standard analytical apps, released analytical queries CDS-based and self-service tooling to create/adjust reports in-app

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0417cd11022d458c83e80fade6cf5d59.html

What you get out of the box (no development) in Public Cloud:

  • Standard sales analytical apps and queries role-based SAP Fiori apps, for example: Sales Volume Detailed Analysis with drilldowns by dimensions like time, sales org, customer, material, etc.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a376cd9ea00d476b96f18dea1247e6a5/21b9cd5780726264e10000000a4450e5.html

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F2235')/S35

  • SAP-delivered analytical queries you can browse and run via Query Browser

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/3a24b854ee8f8d21e10000000a44176d.html

  • CDS view transparency via View Browser to find the underlying released CDS views and see available fields/artifacts

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0bde695751505c08e10000000a441470.html

  • KPI/report creation platform via Manage KPIs and Reports (KPIs, reports, multidimensional reports, stories)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/c00cbf7fe8464663aee830fb6e7eec13.html

  • Example of standard content structure a query like Sales Volume and Open Sales Query is built on a delivered cube view (I_SalesAnalyticsCube)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/c0c54048d35849128be8e872df5bea6d/e63f108b30f24685a9fa6b9db014c6a3.html

No-code / low-code ways to tailor Sales reporting BUT still no dev

  • Custom Analytical Queries: create/copy queries and publish them for reporting/analysis

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/33f3a229ecfe438ca6b2053c48b4e1bb.html

  • Runtime extensibility for queries

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/25ed791bbae342b1bae8451744838cad.html

  • Custom fields + make them available to analytics, for example: you create custom fields in a defined business context and can extend analytics data sources via data source extensions to include additional fields

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/46632054fa9d49a18b452ee287173aba.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/f71b07567568414face7043990335367.html

  • Embedded Stories build stories directly and expose them as tiles in the Fiori launchpad

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/483f3676682a41409be3a71ba486b273.html

Examples of Fiori analytical apps:

Dashboards / overviews

  • Order to Cash Dashboard
  • My Sales Overview
  • Sales Management Overview

Sales volume / order intake analytics

  • Sales Volume Flexible Analysis
  • Sales Volume Detailed Analysis
  • Sales Volume Check Open Sales
  • Incoming Sales Orders Flexible Analysis
  • Sales Performance Plan/Actual
  • Sales Performance Predictions

Sales order fulfillment / delivery reliability analytics

  • Sales Order Items Confirmed as Requested
  • Sales Order Items Backorders
  • Sales Order Fulfillment Analyze and Resolve Issues
  • Predicted Delivery Delay
  • Track Sales Orders

Quotations and contracts analytics

  • Sales Quotations Flexible Analysis
  • Sales Contract Fulfillment Rates Currently Valid

Returns analytics

  • Customer Returns Flexible Analysis
  • Customer Returns Return Rate
  • Customer Returns Overview

Pricing / margin related analytics

  • Pricing Elements Flexible Analysis

Billing monitoring

  • Manage Billing Documents
  • Display Billing Documents

Summary: Public Cloud is powerful and cloud-friendly for Sales reporting without custom coding because it comes with Embedded Analytics (standard Fiori analytical apps and released analytical content on live transactional data)

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: ML currency change during migration ( Bluefield)
entry.content:
Hello @cintgeo ,

Below is my in-line response.

 

QuestionAnswer
1. Can we change ML currencies from 10/30/40 → 10/30/31?Yes, but only BEFORE migration and only via SAP standard conversion framework. You cannot change ML currency types after data load. It impacts ML values because ML is reinitialized during migration.
2. Any impact during the migration?Yes. ML tables are not copied 1-to-1; SAP recalculates opening inventory values and recreates ML structures in S/4HANA based on the new currencies.
3. Do FINSC_LEDGER currencies have to match ML currencies?Yes — in S/4HANA they must match. If ML uses 10/30/31, FINSC_LEDGER must also be 10/30/31. You cannot keep 10/30/40 for BSEG continuity. SAP automatically converts old BSEG values to the new currency types.

If you find my response helpful, share your feedback. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your support.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: How can I to Delete a Subcontracting MRP area?
entry.content:
Hi @jez_lawson ,
You cannot directly delete valid subcontracting MRP areas (type 3) in S/4HANA if they are still linked to materials or have residual assignments. The system enforces this restriction. To remove them, you must first ensure that all material assignments, stocks, and planning elements are cleared, then set the deletion flag in customizing. If the area still refuses deletion, SAP recommends raising a support case, as subcontracting MRP areas behave differently from location-based ones. Now you can Check material assignments (MM02). Ensure no material master is assigned to the subcontracting MRP area. Remove the subcontracting MRP area from the MRP 1/2 views.

Clear stock and planning elements, Verify that no stock exists in the subcontractor’s special stock (O stock). Run MDDIBE to check inconsistencies and clean up. Run YMRPAREO to remove obsolete assignments.

Set deletion flag in customizing. In transaction OMIZB, mark the subcontracting MRP area with a deletion indicator. If the system still blocks deletion, it means dependencies remain hidden. Check for open procurement elements, Ensure no purchase orders, scheduling agreements, or planned orders are linked to the subcontractor.

Again its not allowing then you have to contact sap support

entry.title: MRP Not Converting Demand from Old to New Materials in BOM with Dependent Parallel Discontinuation
entry.content:
Issue: MRP is creating negative requirements on discontinued components instead of converting demand to follow-up materials in a phantom BOM structure.

Setup:

  • Phantom BOM with components A, B, C converting to X, Y, Z
  • Using ECN with dependent parallel configuration via follow-up groups
  • BOM structure:
    • Line item 0021 (FolGp 01): Component A (old) + Component X (new)
    • Line item 0022 (FolGp 01): Component B (old) + Component Y (new)
    • Line item 0023 (FolGp 01): Component C (old) + Component Z (new)
    • All items valid from 10/28/2025
    • Is this perhaps because I have duplicated line items, one with old, one with new? See picture for better BOM setup.

 

 

Material Master Settings:

  • Component A: Disc indicator 1, follow-up material = X
  • Components B & C: Disc indicator 3, no follow-up in material master
  • Follow-up groups configured in BOM discontinuation data (DisGp 01 → FolGp 01)

Problem: When MRP runs and stock depletes on old components, it continues generating negative requirements on A/B/C instead of converting demand to X/Y/Z. Tested with temporary production order and it appeared to work, but actual MRP run doesn't convert, as shown from MD04 transaction on component A. It does appear that the effective out date is considered. It even generated one PO for January '26 for 30pcs.

 

Question: Is there something specific about how MRP handles discontinuation with phantom BOMs? Do I need different effectivity dates on old vs new components, or is there a configuration issue with how the follow-up groups are set up?

Any help appreciated - this is blocking our component transition.

entry.title: Re: retreive filename of a running sql anywhere database
entry.content:
I do this all the time when creating Mobilink environments. I use DB_PROPERTY('Name') since it uniquely identified the database provided that you have good naming practices. Note that DB_PROPERTY can make use of DB_ID to access database properties for other databases on the server. For example, 

select PROPERTY('Name') as EngName, DB_PROPERTY( 'File', DB_ID('demo')) as DBFile

An example framework for my use case is:

-- setup Sync env
-- dbsrv17 -n SetupML ConDB.db RemDB.db

-- create common schema

-- create database specific schema
if( DB_PROPERTY('Name') = 'ConDB' ) then
	-- create schema for the Consolidated DB
end if;

if( DB_PROPERTY('Name') = 'RemDB' ) then
	-- create schema for the Remote DB
end if;

A number of properties are fixed when initially set while others are volatile.  Network addresses can be affected by sa_start_listener and sa_stop_listener while an engine is running.  The listeners may also change between engine runs, depending on changes in network condition (i.e., an IP is offline).

entry.title: ABAP Meets AI: My Hands-On Experience with SAP’s ABAP SDK for LLM Integration
entry.content:
Exciting news for ABAP developers!

SAP has introduced the ABAP SDK powered by ISLM, enabling ABAP developers to access LLMs via SAP AI Core. This breakthrough allows ABAP programs to integrate generative AI directly into the S/4HANA core, delivering seamless AI capabilities.

 

Introduction of ABAP SDK Powered by ISLM for LLM Integration

Late in 2025, SAP introduced the ABAP SDK powered by ISLM, marking a significant advancement for ABAP developers. With this release, for the first time, ABAP programs can seamlessly connect to large language models (LLMs) configured through SAP AI Core. This integration empowers developers to incorporate generative AI capabilities directly within ABAP, unlocking new possibilities for automation, intelligence, and efficiency.

This development represents a groundbreaking innovation for the SAP ecosystem. By embedding AI capabilities directly into the S4 Core, organizations can now leverage advanced AI-powered features natively in their business processes. The seamless integration ensures that generative AI is no longer a side-by-side add-on, but an intrinsic part of the S4HANA environment, enhancing both the power and flexibility available to ABAP developers.

I’ve had the chance to try it out, and being an ABAPer, it’s quite fascinating.

The first use case I wanted to implement was a summarization utility, to test the LLM capabilities within ABAP. To do this, I created an RAP-based program containing lengthy text and utilized LLM to condense it into a meaningful summary. Essentially, I connected the ABAP system to AI Core, which then links to the LLM for summarization. While there are many LLM APIs and functions available from SAP, I started with the basic ones for this initial test. In the upcoming phases, I’ll explore other APIs and functions and share those insights as well.

 

General Concepts and availability

The ABAP AI SDK leverages SAP ISLM to create models that access LLMs configured in SAP AI Core on SAP BTP. This setup allows users to select specific LLM models and versions, effectively integrating SAP AI launchpad features for configuring core LLM models directly within ISLM.

The ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM is available in:

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment 
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and OnPrem as of release 2025 via standard delivery.
  • S4 HANA private cloud version and on-premise 2021 onwards are supported via Transport-based Correction Instructions (TCI), see details in SAP Note 3513374.

Please refer this blog (Joule speaks ABAP! - SAP Community) by Alexander for details on the availability.

 

Configuration and Setup

In this section, we’ll walk through the essential steps needed to set up the ABAP LLM integration. We’ll cover everything from the initial environment setup and prerequisites to the detailed configuration steps. By the end, you’ll have a fully functional integration ready for your ABAP environment.  Please refer sap help document https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-ai/generative-ai-in-abap-cloud/developing-your-own-ai-enabled-applications for complete details and further information on APIs.

My System details

  • System - S4 HANA public cloud instance.
  • LLM used – openAI, gpt-4o-mini, 2024-07-18

Prerequisites

  • SAP AI Core Service subscribed, and instance created (please refer step 4 of my blog to get details).
  • Eclipse with SAP ADT installed and connected to S4 HANA instance.

Summary of Configuration Steps

Step

Activity

System

Application/Details

1

Get S4 HANA system certificate

S4 HANA public Cloud (ABAP system)

Maintain client certificates App

2

Create new service key for AI Core

SAP BTP

SAP AI Core instance

3

Communication system setup

S4 HANA public Cloud (ABAP system)

Communication System App

4

Communication Arrangements setup

S4 HANA public Cloud (ABAP system)

Communication Arrangements App

5

Create Intelligent Scenario

Eclipse ADT

ABAP Perspective

6

Create intelligent scenario model

Eclipse ADT

ABAP Perspective

7

Develop the RAP program

Eclipse ADT

ABAP Perspective

8

Define the prompt

Eclipse ADT

Behavior implementation class

9

Call ISLM scenario

Eclipse ADT

Behavior implementation class

10

Test the output

Eclipse ADT

Business service binding

 

Let's now dive into the specifics of each step.

1. Fetch the SAP ABAP System Client Default Certificate

This certificate is necessary to enable connectivity between the SAP AI Core instance on SAP BTP and the backend ABAP system. Please refer to the following help documentation for additional information.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/fd682bfef603494b9023b1f1b93f27e0.html

2. BTP Service Key and link to the ABAP system using certificate.

During this step, find the SAP AI core instance you set up in SAP BTP and generate a new service key for it.

When generating the key, make sure to populate the “certificate” parameter with the value obtained from the certificate you downloaded from the ABAP system in the previous step.

3. Communication system setup

In this step, we need to create a communication system in the S4 HANA ABAP instance by using FIORI app “Communication System”. Please use the values generated in the newly created key in the step above to fill parameters. Details of values to be used and steps are mentioned in below SAP help. Please note that wherever you are maintaining the hyperlink, remove the “https://”.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0d8de8180954443db83a2ceb127b8734.html

4. Communication Arrangement setup.

Now that the communication system is set up, next step is to connect thus communication system to a communication arrangement. Please use the SAP provided scenario ID:  SAP_COM_0A69 (SAP AI Core - GenAI - Customer Outbound Integration) and use the communication system which was setup in the previous step. Details can be found in the help below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/16d3b0ed27b64bebb4f1ccdac7663ba0.html

5. Create Intelligent Scenario in Eclipse.

By now, we have completed the connection between BTP and ABAP system. Next step would be to create the ISLM scenario to connect the AI core with the ABAP system.

You can do this by logging into your ABAP system via Eclipse ADT and selecting option create intelligent scenarios. Details in the help below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-development-tools-user-guide/creating-intelligent-scenarios

In here, you may choose SAPGENAI as the type and technology as SIDEBYSIDE.

6. Create intelligent scenario model.

The intelligent scenario that has been created now requires linkage to a model. Please select the scenario developed in the previous step and then choose the appropriate LLM models and versions.

https://help.sap.com/docs/abap-cloud/abap-development-tools-user-guide/creating-intelligent-scenario-models

7. Develop the RAP program

In here, I have developed a simple managed RAP based program to fetch entries from a table. I have created a service definition and binding with UI to test the app.

I developed an implementation based on the behavior definition, and all of the following source code originates from that behavior definition class.  I have created a button for summarizing the selected row. This code is implemented in the button event handler method.

8. Prompt Definition.

Designing a prompt is essential for each AI use case.  Since I am using LLM/AI to summarize a text, I have used the prompt below in the behavior implementation class.

9. Create instance and call the ISLM instance from ABAP Program.

Now, use this prompt to create and an instance of ISLM model. Use CL_AIC_ISLM_COMPL_API_FACTORY=>GET to obtain a factory instance (IF_AIC_ISLM_COMPL_API_FACTORY). Then call CREATE_INSTANCE on the factory, passing only the intelligent scenario name. This returns a new completion API instance (IF_AIC_COMPLETION_API), as the scenario contains all connection and model details.

The completion AI can be called by using the method execute_for_string  as shown below, which responds the result as type string in variable “result”.

Once the result is available from LLM, I will use that text to update the table back with the summarized description.

10. Final Output and Testing

Here is the final output. You can see that once we click on “Fill Summary”, it calls the LLM, summarizes the long description and populates that into the short description field.

 

Conclusion

Integrating LLMs directly into ABAP makes life much easier for developers, removing the need to learn entirely new technologies. Now, ABAP developers can use LLMs within their familiar environment, making it simpler to unlock new possibilities and drive innovation.

Stay tuned, I will be sharing new blogs soon, exploring even more advanced uses of the ABAP SDK.

entry.title: Re: product/material char 18 to 40 SAP public cloud-Is It...
entry.content:
Hi @vasudev_Rao78 ,

It is not technically possible to increase the material number (MATNR/Product) length from 18 to 40 characters in S/4HANA Public Cloud; the configuration switch available in on‑premise (e.g., OMSL) is not exposed in Public Cloud and cannot be activated post go‑live. In contrast, S/4HANA on‑premise (from release 1511) supports extending MATNR to 40 characters and uses a different activation path and impacts, but that option applies to on‑premise and older cloud editions where such customizing was available

entry.title: Transformation from DTAZV to pain 001.001.09 New EBS Formats
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I’m working on replacing the old DTAZV format with pain.001.001.09 in our SAP ECC (R/3) system.
The pain.001.001.09 format is already implemented and works correctly in other payment scenarios(In F110) and this was done by following 2253571 SAP Note, but for this specific case( Auslandsüberweisung ) the generated EBS is not valid according to the bank requirements.

I am aware of SAP Note 3187339, but since we are on an ECC/R3 system, the note is not applicable to our release.

My question is:

Does this mean that on R/3 the transformation from DTAZV to pain.001.001.09 must be manually adjusted (DMEE/customizing), or is there any SAP-delivered configuration for this format that I might be missing?

If anyone has experience with this transition on ECC, I would appreciate any guidance or best practices.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recoverability of dropped tables?
entry.content: Why would SAP not turn Recyclebin on to help in recoverability of dropped tables similar to how they "don't recommend ASMM".  It is as if they are trying to stop all features that enhance the recoverability in Oracle, like if a user accidentally drops a table.  The recommended setting for Oracle Recyclebin is "OFF" from SAP's notes.  Has anyone else ignored this and ran with the Recyclebin setting "ON?"

entry.title: Re: Can you schedule a provisioning job for Bonus Calc/Bo...
entry.content: This is correct, bonus calculation is not available to be scheduled as a stand alone.   You can initiate a bonus calculation as part of the employee history import.   I do not believe the interim step of a Variable Pay Basis Amount Calculation is necessary.

entry.title: Re: Add Indexes in SQL DB SAP IDM
entry.content:
Not speaking for SAP, but adding non-unique secondary indices should not be any problem since they change nothing from a functional perspective. Unique indices, however, would obviously be a problem.

But just out of curiosity: which queries exactly are you trying to optimize by introducing these indices? I found that SAP's index coverage is pretty complete for all use cases that I have run into - so maybe the problem is not a missing index, but some custom SQL queries that would need redesign?

entry.title: Successfactors Compensation Worksheet - MDF
entry.content:
HI experts,

In my salary review worksheet , I need to create a custom column that reads my custom MDF "Education".
In the parent object, there is the field external code set as user, but the other useful fields to include in my worksheet are not there because they are in the child object linked to the parent MDF.
How can I make the worksheet also read the fields from the child MDF?
Do I need to set the external code as user here as well? We have set it as autonumber since it can contain multiple entries per day.

Thanks
